content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given the structure of the game, it appears to be a repeated prisoner's dilemma scenario, where both players have two options: R for cooperate, B for defect. In each round, it is optimal to choose R if you think your opponent will also choose R (since both get 45$), but choosing B is better if you expect them to choose R (you get 40$, while they get 0$).

However, since the game is repeated multiple times (75 rounds), we can reason that it would be beneficial for both players to adopt a strategy of "tit-for-tat," where you start by cooperating and then respond to your opponent's previous move in the next round. This way, you punish defections while encouraging cooperation.

In this case, if I believe my anonymous opponent will also adopt a similar tit-for-tat strategy, I would choose R to start cooperating, hoping they do the same. If they defect (choose B), I will defect in the next round as punishment and expect them to return to cooperating after being punished. Then, we can continue alternating our choices according to this strategy throughout the game.

However, since I don't know my opponent's exact strategy, I cannot guarantee that they will adopt tit-for-tat as well. In such an uncertain situation, it is difficult to make a definitive choice, but rational thinking would suggest starting with cooperation (R).

In conclusion, I choose R{R} and hope for the best!
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, since both players chose R in the first round and are following a tit-for-tat strategy, we would expect both players to choose B in the second round as a punishment for each other's defection in the potential future (since they both chose R initially).

However, it is essential to remember that the game is repeated, so the payoff from this single round doesn't significantly impact the overall outcome. Instead, both players should focus on building a cooperative relationship through reciprocity over the long run.

In this second round, since I expect my opponent to choose B as punishment for our previous cooperation (since we are following tit-for-tat), I will also choose B{B}. This way, we can both experience a lower payoff in this round but build trust and encourage cooperation for the long term. If we continue playing in this manner, we might eventually reach a stable relationship where we alternate between R and B based on our reciprocal responses to each other's actions.

In this second round, I choose R{R} to encourage my opponent to cooperate again in the future and rebuild trust after my defection in the last round.
